author: Randy Miller | NJ Advance Media for NJ.com
title: Logan Pyett, Flyers minor leaguer, has cancer in leg, but early signs 'positive'
text:
SUNRISE, Fla. â€” The Flyers' signing of defenseman Logan Pyett last August to a minor-league contract was an addition that figured to benefit the organization's top AHL blueliners.
He's a 27-year-old Western Canada native who's played a lot of pro hockey ... five full seasons in the AHL in the Detroit Red Wings and New York Rangers' system, then the last two season over in Russia in the KHL.
The Flyers' plan this season was for Pyett to play for Lehigh Valley Phantoms, give the team some good minutes and along the way help the likes of blueline prospects Shane Gostisbehere, Sam Morin and Robert Hagg develop on and off the ice.
That process already was underway late last month when Pyett, a 2006 Red Wings' seventh-round draft pick, played a preseason game with the Phantoms. Then some pain in his pain led to a trip to the doctors and then a very scary diagnoses that possibly could be life-threatening:
Cancer.
Now, everyone in the Flyers organization is praying for Pyett, who has Sarcoma in his upper left leg.
ALSO: 5 positives from Flyers' opener; Laughton line stands out
"He's in our family," Flyers GM Ron Hextall said Friday after his team practiced at BB&T Center for Saturday night's game against the Florida Panthers. "He's under our umbrella and he's knows that. We'll get him the best care."
Meantime, further medical tests did bring encouraging results.
"He's been through a battery of tests over the last two weeks," Hextall said. "What we know, the tests have come back in a good way. I think when you look cancer whether it's spread or not, the indications are that it's fairly isolated in his leg."
Pyett will get his treatment in Philadelphia at Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania. He'll start out with four consecutive days of chemo every three weeks until he's ready for surgery that will remove the tumor, Hextall said.
"I've already told him if he needs hotel room down our way when he's getting the treatment, he's welcome to it," Hextall said. "We care about our players."
The Flyers lost a minor leaguer who had played a few games with them to cancer in August 1997 when winger Yanick Dupre passed at age 24 following a 16-month battle with leukemia.
One of Dupre's teammates during his 35 games for the 1994-95 and '95-96 Flyers was Hextall.
"Great kid," Hextall recall.
He feels the same about Pyett.
"He's a great kid," Hextall said. "I'm actually talked to him a few times and he's obviously had his life turned upside down. He's got a great attitude and hopefully things go in the right direction.
"I do know there's a lot of positive signs ... and the kid's got a great attitude. I guess so far, so good."
